data.text: Contents
Introduction
Clinical Relevance/Purpose of the Test
The Bilimeter  may be used for production of rapid quantitative total bilirubin results for use in the assessment and monitoring of neonatal jaundice.

Neonatal jaundice associated with an elevated serum bilirubin level is a common physiological condition occurring shortly after birth due to immaturity of hepatic systems, and usually resolves without treatment. However, a high concentration of bilirubin can cause brain damage (kernicterus) and requires investigation of the underlying cause. A dangerously high level of bilirubin is treated by phototherapy or exchange transfusion.
Principle of the Test

The Bilimeter  is a bilirubinometer designed for in-vitro spectrophotometric measurement of total bilirubin in neonates. The device measures the absorbance of bilirubin at 455nm through plasma in a capillary tube. The sample is blanked at 575nm to correct for interference from haemoglobin, which is the only interfering pigment in un-weaned neonates.
Scope

Point of Care Testing (POCT) is an established part of clinical practice, offering in many instances, rapid and convenient provision of test results that can be of benefit to the patient. It is however, a significant risk management issue for the Trust. Results obtained by non-specialist staff carry as much weight in patient management as results from sophisticated equipment in the care of professional laboratory staff. Incorrect results have the same health and legal implications, whatever their origin.

The purpose of this document is to ensure reliable performance and management of the risks associated with testing outside the main laboratory. This procedure describes correct use of POCT equipment in order to minimise risk to both patient and user, and ensure consistent procedures are in place throughout the Trust.

Individuals who have not been trained and competency assessed in the use of the Bilimeter 3 are not authorised to use this device. This document has not been written as a substitute for practical training and competency assessment offered by designated Trust staff and the Point of Care Testing Team.
Definitions

table_items.text: The performance of analytical tests on patient specimens outside the laboratory by non-laboratory staff.
Any individual using a POCT device.

Internal quality control (QC) is a means of determining that the POCT equipment is technically performing correctly at that specific time and that the patient result is reliable before it is released and acted on.
External quality assessment (EQA) is a means of determining how a particular POCT device is performing in comparison to similar devices elsewhere.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Committees/Teams
Point of Care Testing Committee

The POCT committee is responsible for overseeing and co-ordinating all aspects of the POCT service within their Trust. Clinical Governance for POCT services is provided through the POCT policy. This policy is reviewed and updated every 2 years as a collaborative effort between committees at both SUH and BTUH Trusts.
POCT Operational Team

This team comprises of relevant personnel from Pathology First. Teams should be adequately resourced to enable them to implement and monitor compliance with the POCT policy and procedure. They are responsible for ensuring any recommendations imposed on the service by the committee are carried out.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
Chief Executive/Medical Director/Director of Nursing

As the accountable officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring SUH and BTUH have robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal, and national requirements are met.
Responsible for the implementation of this policy.
Pathology Clinical Director
Holds the ultimate responsibility for Point of Care Testing as guardian of Clinical Governance.
Advises and arbitrates if necessary if agreement about the introduction of a POCT service cannot be reached.
Ensures guidelines are in place for interpretation of results and further patient management.
Clinical Lead for POCT
Has clinical oversight for Point of Care Testing, liaising between the Trust and Pathology First on matters including current testing protocols and implementation of new equipment/ tests.
Holds the role of Chairperson of the Point of Care Testing Committee.
Reviews POCT EQA and reports upon it.
4.2.4 Heads of Nursing and Midwifery and Matrons
Heads of nursing and midwifery and matrons have a responsibility to ensure correct procedures are followed.
4.2.5 Ward or Departmental Managers
To take on managerial ownership of any POCT equipment within their area and to ensure that it is maintained and used correctly.
They will ensure the competency of all users of POCT in their area. They will keep records of initial training, competency statements and update training.

If appropriate they will appoint a link person to oversee the day-to-day operation of POCT equipment within their area. The use of a Link Person does not absolve the ward/department manager of full responsibility for POCT

Where there has been an incident involving POCT devices, including inadequate performance or documentation of patient or Quality Assurance results, Ward or Departmental managers will investigate the incident and be responsible for reporting this to POCT. All such incidents should be brought to the attention of the POCT manager and the POCT committee.
Any request for new, upgraded or replacement POCT processes must be submitted to the POCT committee for approval. This includes free, trial and loan
devices.
4.2.6 Point of Care Testing Link Person

A Link Person may be designated within a ward/department for the purpose of ensuring the day to day operation of POCT systems, ensuring equipment is functioning and necessary consumables are available. They may provide cascade training, having been trained to a high level of competence, ensuring staff undertaking POCT are suitable to do so.
4.2.7 Pharmacy
Pharmacy is responsible for standardising, ordering and supplying the majority of POCT consumables as directed by the POCT committee.
4.2.8 POCT Operations Manager & Team Manager

The POCT service managers monitor the POCT service within each Trust. They ensure that POCT policies and procedures are adhered to and that adequate resources and support from Pathology First are available to facilitate a safe and reliable service.
4.2.9 Clinicians
To identify areas of clinical need where the introduction of POCT could be appropriate and provide the information necessary for the cost-benefit analysis.
To approach POCT in the spirit of the policy and not to attempt to introduce new testing without referring to the POCT policy.
To undertake POCT themselves only after adequate training and certification.
To be familiar with the information provided by and shortcomings of the POCT results that they use for their patient management.
To ensure that results of POCT are recorded accurately, unequivocally and safely and that information about tests upon which they base patient management decisions can be retrieved in retrospect.
The responsibility for patient results obtained using POCT and therapeutic decisions based on those results lies with the requesting clinician for the ward/department.
4.2.10 All Users

The individual conducting the analysis is accountable for the results they generate using POCT devices. They must ensure their POCT training is up to date and that their competence is maintained. It is the responsibility of the user:

To follow procedures as set out in the documented Standard Operating Procedure, including sample taking and handling, instrument checks and/or Quality Control, recording of results and disposal of consumables.
To undertake and record External Quality Control analysis as required.

To report suspect Quality Control results or possible instrument malfunction immediately to the Link person or person in charge at the time and to stop using the equipment until the matter has been resolved.
To report abnormal or suspect patient results to the responsible person immediately
To report adverse incidents related to POCT devices to the Link nurse where used and to the POCT team.
Instructions for use
Health & Safety/COSHH
5.1.1 Users must make use of personal protective equipment (PPE) when handling patient samples according to Trust policy.
5.1.2 Waste must be disposed of according to Trust policy.
5.1.3 The device should be cleaned with Clinell universal sanitising wipes. A decontamination certificate may be issued before servicing and repair as required.
5.1.4 Bloodstained putty sealant blocks must be discarded as clinical waste.
5.1.5 In order to safely use the Haematocrit Centrifuge:
The rotor must be firmly in place;
No persons or dangerous materials should be within 30cm of the centrifuge whilst it is running;
The centrifuge must not be knocked or moved whilst running;
In case of fault or emergency release, never touch the rotor before it has stopped turning;
The centrifuge must be balanced (within the bounds of acceptability).
Special Precautions
5.2.1 To ensure that the Bilimeter 3 functions properly place the device as follows:
Horizontally on a flat vibration free surface;
In a well ventilated area, not in direct sunshine or where there is much dust;
At a room temperature of between 15 and 30 degrees centigrade;
In an area where the humidity is under 70%;
Away from strong magnetic fields;
Protected from corrosive, flammable or volatile gases/vapours;
5.2.2 To ensure the Haematocrit Centrifuge functions properly it must be placed on a stable surface.
Equipment & Special Supplies
5.3.1  This procedure requires:
Pfaff Bilimeter 3 (supplied in the UK by Sartorius);
Haematocrit Centrifuge (supplied by Hettich);
Pfaff Bilimeter capillary tubes (available from the POCT team (SUH)/ ordered by ward (BTUH));
Sealing putty (available from the POCT team (SUH)/ ordered by ward (BTUH));
Record of Neonatal Bilirubin Patient Results book (available from the POCT team, Pathology).
Reagents
5.4.1  No reagents are required.
Calibration
5.5.1  The Bilimeter is calibrated at manufacture and this is checked yearly as part of the engineer's maintenance.
Internal Quality Control (IQC)

5.6.1 To ensure that the meter is working correctly and producing accurate results the Bilimeter should be checked at least once per day using the technical internal quality control (IQC) Prüfsonde. The Prüfsonde IQC should also be processed if the Bilimeter is moved or switched off.
5.6.2 Please note that the Prüfsonde must always be:
Removed from the Bilimeter after use to prevent overheating;
Stored at room temperature and kept dry (never store in the refrigerator);
Kept free from dust (clean with a small soft brush but do not touch the glass insert);
Protected from light.

5.6.3 The Prüfsonde IQC produces results on the meter that must fall within a pre-defined range determined by the manufacturer of the meter. The Prüfsonde IQC results must be reported in the ward's IQC log, together with the operator's initials.

5.6.4 The meter must only be used on patient samples if the IQC checks are within acceptable limits. If the IQC result does not fall within the target range, re-zero the Bilimeter, and repeat the IQC procedure. If it is still outside the range the POCT team should be contacted and the device must not be used for patient samples until authorised by the POCT team.
5.6.5 Performing Internal Quality Control (IQC)

table_items.text: Ensure the Bilimeter 3 is switched off
Pull out the cell holder from the instrument and confirm the following: a) A capillary tube is not present in the cell holder b) The cell holder is dust free and clean

Place the clean cell holder into the instrument without a capillary tube present. Switch on the Bilimeter 3. Countdown will start from '30 to 0'. When the display shows ‘0.0µmol/L' preparation is complete. If the instrument is ZERO'd while a capillary tube is inserted in the cell holder, zero adjustment will not be completed and patient results will not be accurate.
Remove the Prüfsonde (Coloured Quality Control Filter) from the box where it is stored.
Insert the Prüfsonde into the meter, coloured spot on the top.
The result should be shown on the display.
Before proceeding any further, ensure that the result falls within the stated range. If the result falls outside the range contact the Point of Care Team.
Record result in the folder provided with operator name, date & time of the test.

data.text: External Quality Assurance (EQA)
5.7.1 The POCT team obtain External Quality Assurance (EQA) samples on a monthly basis. These samples are analysed by the POCT team.
5.7.2 Samples are processed in the same way as patient samples (see section 5.6) omitting the centrifugation step.
Sample Collection and Handling

5.8.1 A whole blood sample is usually obtained from a clean dry heel into a Pfaff Bilimeter capillary tube and sealed with putty. The area of skin to be lanced should be warm and relaxed. It should be cleaned with water and dried to avoid interference from contaminants on the skin or dilution from water used for washing. Alternatively, blood can be taken from indwelling venous or arterial lines.
5.8.2 If a phototherapy unit is in use, this should be switched off while obtaining the sample.
5.8.3 A very small amount of serum is required for bilirubin analysis and the capillary tube should only be ½ to ¾ filled with blood.

5.8.4 Blood samples containing bilirubin are extremely sensitive to light and heat, therefore once a sample has been taken it should be spun down and measured as quickly as possible to prevent erroneous results
5.8.5 Using the Hettich Haematokrit 210 Centrifuge

table_items.text: Ensure gloves are worn at all times.
Obtain a capillary tube of the patients' blood.

Seal one end of the tube with the putty provided. It should be sealed by placing the capillary at a 90° angle to the putty block and twisting the capillary. The block should be replaced as required. If the capillary tube is placed at a 45° angle and putty is scooped into the tube, this will not seal properly under centrifugation and the sample will be spun out.
Open the centrifuge by unlocking on the front panel, which will release the lid.
Remove rotor cover by depressing centre button and lifting cover

Place the capillary into a slot with the putty facing outwards. Always ensure that the rotor is balanced (e.g. If only one specimen is to be centrifuged, another capillary filled with water should be placed opposite so that the rotor is balanced as it spins).
Replace the rota cover ensuring that a click is heard
Shut the centrifuge lid and lock
The centrifuge should be set to 130 (1300 rpm) and the time set for 7 minutes.
At the end of the cycle the lid can be unlocked, the rota lid removed and the sample taken out for analysis.

data.text: Note: As long as the Bilimeter 3 has been properly controlled and the results of the QC are recorded in the correct place, you can proceed and carry out a patient test.
5.8.6 Performing patient sample analysis

table_items.text: Processing the Sample on the Bilimeter 3
Ensure the bilirubinometer is switched on and ready for use.
Zero the machine as described above if it has been in standby for a long time.
Ensure the daily Internal Quality Control sample has been performed and that the result is within the stated range.
Place the capillary in the sample holder with the separated serum/plasma across the slit. The slit must be completely covered by the serum fluid column.
Put the sample holder with the patient's sample into the instrument. The measurement will start automatically.
The value of the total bilirubin is indicated in digital numbers.
Record result in the folder provided with operator name, date & time of the test.These results must be kept in accordance with national guidelines (See reference 6).
All measured samples should be disposed of in the sharps bin.

Recording and Interpretation of Results
5.9.1 Recording Results
All results must be recorded in the patient's medical record, and include:
Date & time of the test
Bilirubin result
o  Designated, for example, as ‘Bilirubin (POCT)' to avoid confusion with results from the lab
Name of person who carried out the test
Results may also be recorded on the appropriate NICE Treatment Threshold Graph.
Additionally, patient results may be recorded in the Record of Neonatal Bilirubin Patient Results book provided by POCT.
5.9.2 Reference Range
Results should be interpreted in view of all available clinical information.
If the test result is questionable or if clinical signs and symptoms appear inconsistent with the test result, re-test with a fresh sample or confirm the result by sending a sample to the laboratory.
5.9.3 Alert/Critical Values
The NICE Treatment Threshold Graphs are used to define phototherapy and exchange transfusion treatment thresholds at the appropriate week's gestation.
Results should be escalated to senior staff as appropriate according to local protocols.
Limitations
5.10.1 Test only suitable for use in un-weaned neonates.
5.10.2 Umbilical cord blood is not suitable for analysis.

5.10.3 Care should be taken if babies are on TPN containing lipids. Highly lipaemic samples (plasma appears cloudy) are not suitable for analysis. Ideally samples should be taken 4 hours after the TPN has been stopped.

5.10.4 Blood samples containing bilirubin are extremely sensitive to light and heat, therefore once a sample has been taken it should be spun down and measured as quickly as possible to prevent erroneous results.
5.10.5 Only the approved Pfaff Bilimeter capillary tubes should be used for the test, to ensure optical quality.
5.10.6 Capillary tubes must be clean and undamaged. Either of these factors could affect the optical reading of the sample once placed into the analyser, and cause erroneous results.
5.10.7 The measurement slit must be centred in the plasma to ensure accurate absorbance reading of the plasma portion of the sample (rather than red cells).

5.10.8 The capillary tube must be removed from the device immediately after measurement. If the capillary tube is left inside the device, the sample is exposed to continued light which breaks down bilirubin and results in a lower reading.

5.10.9 The capillary holder measure slit should not be cleaned with any metallic or sharp object that may scratch the black paint from the capillary holder, as this will cause internal light scattering which will give erroneous results.
Maintenance

5.11.1 It is the ward's responsibility to keep the centrifuge socially clean, and the users' responsibility to wipe the centrifuge with a Clinell wipe after each use. This includes removing and cleaning the padded shells where necessary.
5.11.2 A yearly service and calibration is carried out by a Pfaff/Sartorius engineer.
Performance Criteria
5.12.1 The measuring range is 0-1690 µmol/L.
Basic Troubleshooting & Error Messages

Remove and replace with the black dot facing upwards
Zero adjustment was performed with a patient sample in the capillary holder
Remove capillary from holder and re-zero

Training Requirements

The test should only be carried out by a trained member of staff. Each staff member accepts responsibility for ensuring the quality of all monitoring carried out by themselves. The staff member must ensure their Bilimeter 3 training is updated and that their competence to perform tests on this instrument is maintained. Practical training and competence assessment is available via the POCT team.
Monitoring and Audit
All Clinical Unit managers are responsible for monitoring the Bilimeter 3 machine in their area. They must ensure that the standard operating procedure is followed on a day to day basis.

The POCT team will perform audit on the use of the Bilimeter 3 machines and report their findings to the appropriate Clinical Unit Manager, Matron and governance leads. A copy will also be sent to the Director of Nursing, Infection control, Risk and Litigation and the POCT committee.

It is the author's responsibility to inform the service users of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
